definition:
Let $X$ be a Hausdorff topological space. A basis for $X$ is said to be
a *uniform base* if for all $x\in X$ and every neighborhood $U$ of $x$,
only a finite number of the basis sets containing $x$ intersect the
complement of $U$.

For example, in any metric space, the open balls of radius $\frac{1}{n}$
form a uniform base of $X$.

Any uniform base of $X$ is a point countable base.

[9]{} Steen, Lynn Arthur and Seebach, J. Arthur, *Counterexamples in
Topology*, Dover Books, 1995.
